bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Roger Brooke, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Hench thanks Brooke for the photo of the Camp Columbia model and asks if he may send a copy of it to the Cuban government.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Roger Brooke, September 12, 1940

opener.dateline:
September 12, 1940 Brig. General Roger Brooke
The Medical Field Service School
Carlisle Barracks
Carlisle, Pa.

div1.p:
I cannot tell you how much I appreciate the photographs of
the model of Camp Columbia, Havana, 1900. Your photographs, as a matter of
fact, are much better than those taken by the Army Medical Museum, and it
was a happy idea to have the photograph out on the grass somewhere. The whole
thing looks like a very realistic airplane photograph. I had hoped to be able
to send you a copy of a rather detailed memorandum on the yellow fever experi-
ments which I have prepared, to be revised by General Kean, General Truby and
others connected with the work of Walter Reed. Unfortunately, our machine
would only make seven copies, and these are all out being corrected. When I
can, I will send it to you, not only because I think it will interest you as a
physician, but it will show you how important the photographs of the model are
to me in identifying the true location of Camp Lazear. The railroad track in
your model is still there, but of course Camp Lazear was a mile away, and not
by the railroad track as they now have it marked. Thank you most kindly indeed
for your real courtesy in sending me these photographs.

May I have your permission to have them copied here so that I
may have extra copies, one to send to the Cuban government so that they may
relocate Camp Lazear? I should also like to have a supply, to be used in
connection with my address.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
